annotation.summary: Actions are the primary means by which players influence the game world, especially regulated during encounters but still relevant outside them.
annotation.action_economy: Defines that actions are the core unit of player activity, tracked strictly in encounters.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies universally to all characters and situations.

annotation.summary: At the start of each turn in an encounter, a character regains 3 actions and 1 reaction to use during that round, which can be spent in various ways.
annotation.prerequisites: Must be participating in an encounter with defined turns.

annotation.summary: Describes the four categories of actions available to characters: single actions, activities, reactions, and free actions.
Single actions are brief, self-contained activities that produce their effects within the duration of that one action.
annotation.action_economy: Single action
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: Activities are complex actions that require multiple actions performed consecutively. For example, Double Tap is an activity combining the Aim and Strike actions to produce its effect.
annotation.action_economy: Requires multiple actions used in succession; Double Tap uses both Aim and Strike actions.
annotation.prerequisites: Must be able to perform the component actions (e.g., Aim and Strike).

annotation.summary: Reactions are special actions that occur in response to specific triggers, which can happen at any time, even outside your turn. Their use outside of encounters is subject to the GM's discretion.
annotation.action_economy: Uses your reaction when its trigger condition is met.
annotation.prerequisites: A valid trigger must occur to use a reaction.

annotation.summary: Free actions require no action or reaction cost. Those without triggers must be used on your turn like a single action, while those with triggers function like reactions and can be used whenever their trigger occurs.
annotation.action_economy: No cost; functions as a single action or reaction depending on trigger presence.
annotation.prerequisites: Must have a free action available; triggered free actions require a valid trigger condition.

annotation.summary: An activity combines multiple actions to achieve a greater or distinct effect, though some activities, such as certain spells, may require only a single action, reaction, or free action.
annotation.action_economy: Varies; typically multiple actions, but can be 1 action, 1 reaction, or 1 free action.
annotation.prerequisites: None explicitly stated.

annotation.summary: Activities can include specific actions that are already accounted for in the activity’s total action cost, so no extra actions are required to perform them.
annotation.action_economy: The actions within an activity do not require additional action expenditure beyond the activity’s listed cost.
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: An activity requires spending all its actions at once to gain its effects. During encounters, it must be completed within your turn, and if interrupted or disrupted, all committed actions are lost.
annotation.action_economy: All actions for the activity must be spent simultaneously during your turn.
annotation.prerequisites: None explicitly stated; applies when performing an activity in an encounter.

annotation.summary: Activities outside of encounters can take extended periods and are typically marked with exploration or downtime traits. Minor actions can be performed alongside them, but not other major activities.
annotation.action_economy: Varies; measured in minutes, hours, or days rather than turns or actions.
annotation.prerequisites: Must be outside of an encounter; cannot perform another significant activity simultaneously.

annotation.summary: When a non-encounter activity is interrupted or disrupted, the time already spent is lost, but no extra time is added to complete it later.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; applies outside of encounters.
annotation.prerequisites: An ongoing activity outside of an encounter that can be disrupted.

annotation.summary: Reactions and triggered free actions can only be used when their specific trigger conditions occur, and using them is optional even when the trigger happens.
annotation.action_economy: Reactions and free actions are limited by their triggers; they can only be used when the listed event occurs.
annotation.prerequisites: A valid trigger event must occur for the reaction or free action to be available.

annotation.summary: All characters have access to a limited set of basic reactions and free actions, while additional actions are typically granted by class features, feats, or magic items.
annotation.prerequisites: None; all characters have access to basic reactions and free actions by default.

annotation.summary: The paragraph introduces the concept that reactions and certain abilities in stat blocks have specific triggers that determine when they can be used.
annotation.action_economy: Reaction
annotation.prerequisites: Ability or feature must specify a trigger in its stat block.

annotation.summary: You can only use one action in response to a single trigger, even if multiple actions share that trigger. If triggers are similar but not identical, the GM decides whether they count as separate or the same based on the narrative context.
annotation.action_economy: Limits responses to one action per trigger; GM determines overlap for similar triggers.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires having multiple actions or reactions with defined triggers.

annotation.summary: Each creature can take only one action per trigger, but multiple creatures can respond to the same trigger. If simultaneous actions cause ambiguity, the GM decides their order according to the narrative.
annotation.action_economy: One action per trigger per creature; multiple creatures may act on the same trigger.
annotation.prerequisites: A trigger that allows a reaction or free action; GM present to resolve timing conflicts.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains how to handle actions not explicitly defined in the rules, specifying that the game provides guidance on how many actions such tasks require and what traits they have. It also notes that Game Masters can apply this method when adjudicating unlisted actions.
annotation.action_economy: Undefined actions are assigned an action cost and relevant traits as determined by the rules or the Game Master.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies whenever a player or Game Master encounters an undefined action.

annotation.summary: This paragraph explains that certain effects or conditions can alter how many actions a character can take on their turn. The slowed condition reduces available actions, while the quickened condition increases them. When losing actions, the player chooses which actions to lose, and some effects like the haste spell grant extra but limited actions.
annotation.action_economy: Effects can increase or decrease the number of actions available per turn. Players choose which actions to lose when required, and some gained actions may have restrictions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies generally to any character affected by conditions or effects that modify available actions.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains varying levels of action restriction in the game. Some effects prevent reactions, while the most severe—being unable to act—prohibits all actions and speech. Even when unable to act, a character still regains actions unless another condition stops it.
annotation.action_economy: Describes how certain effects limit or remove available actions and reactions, including total inability to act.
annotation.prerequisites: Triggered by specific effects or conditions that restrict actions or reactions.

annotation.summary: When an action is disrupted by certain abilities or conditions, the character still spends the actions, reactions, and resources used, but the intended effects of the action do not occur.
annotation.action_economy: The spent actions or reactions are consumed even though the action fails to produce effects.
annotation.prerequisites: An ability or condition capable of disrupting an action, such as a Reactive Strike.

annotation.summary: The paragraph introduces clarifications regarding how actions are used within the game system.
annotation.action_economy: General explanation of action usage; no specific mechanics detailed.
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: Free actions with triggers and reactions can be used immediately when their trigger occurs, even if it happens during another action.
annotation.action_economy: Free actions and reactions occur outside the normal turn structure and can interrupt other actions when their trigger conditions are met.
annotation.prerequisites: A defined trigger condition must occur for the free action or reaction to be used.

annotation.summary: Describes how some actions can include simpler 'subordinate' actions, such as Basic Actions, with modified circumstances or effects. The subordinate action retains its normal traits and triggers but only gains new traits if explicitly stated. The cost of performing the subordinate action is already included in the larger action’s cost.
annotation.action_economy: The subordinate action does not require additional actions or reactions; its cost is included in the larger action.
annotation.prerequisites: A larger action that specifies the use of a subordinate action.

annotation.summary: Clarifies that performing an activity is distinct from performing its component actions. Effects or conditions that grant or modify actions, such as the quickened condition from haste, apply only to individual actions like Stride or Strike, not to entire activities that include those actions.
annotation.action_economy: Activities consume the number of actions they require as a whole; extra or modified actions cannot substitute for or be used within an activity unless explicitly allowed.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies generally to all uses of actions and activities.

annotation.summary: If an activity is disrupted before completion, all actions already spent on that activity are lost for the turn.
annotation.action_economy: Losing all actions committed to a disrupted multi-action activity within the same turn.
annotation.prerequisites: The character must be performing an activity that requires multiple actions, such as casting a spell.

annotation.summary: When an action is disrupted, the GM determines any additional consequences beyond canceling the action’s intended effect, such as dropped items or incomplete movement.
annotation.action_economy: Varies depending on the disrupted action; the disrupted action is lost.
annotation.prerequisites: An action must be disrupted before its completion.

annotation.summary: Basic actions are fundamental tasks like moving, attacking, or assisting that all creatures can perform under normal circumstances. They serve as the foundation for more complex actions and activities, which may combine or modify these basic actions to create varied effects.
annotation.action_economy: Basic actions typically use one action each, and can be combined or modified by feats or activities.
annotation.prerequisites: None; all creatures can perform basic actions unless restricted by specific conditions.

annotation.summary: Specialty Basic Actions are uncommon actions available to most creatures but require specific conditions or abilities, such as using a shield, having a burrow speed, or being in free fall.
annotation.action_economy: Varies depending on the specific action; generally follows standard action rules.

annotation.summary: The paragraph directs readers to where they can find rules for spellcasting actions and magic item actions in the rulebook.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified; refers to other sections for details.
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: Describes two options for altering turn timing: Delay allows a character to postpone their entire turn, while Ready lets them prepare a specific action to perform when a chosen trigger occurs.
annotation.action_economy: Delay uses no specific action but postpones the turn; Ready requires using an action to set up a triggered response.
annotation.prerequisites: Must be able to act on your turn and specify a trigger for the Ready action.

annotation.summary: The character can choose to delay their turn, removing themselves from the initiative order until they decide to re-enter as a free action at the end of another creature's turn, permanently changing their initiative to that new position. While delayed, they cannot use reactions, and if they wait an entire round without re-entering, they lose their delayed actions and retain their original initiative position.
annotation.action_economy: Free action to return to initiative order; forfeits current turn actions while delayed.
annotation.prerequisites: Must have a turn available in the initiative order to delay.

annotation.summary: Using the Delay action causes all start- or end-of-turn effects, both harmful and beneficial, to resolve immediately. You cannot use Delay to avoid negative effects or prolong beneficial ones, and the GM may rule that other effects also end when you Delay.
annotation.action_economy: 1 action (used on your turn to postpone your initiative position)
annotation.prerequisites: You must be able to act on your turn and choose to Delay before taking other actions.

annotation.summary: The character attempts to free themselves from a condition such as grabbed, immobilized, or restrained by making a check against the DC of the effect. The check can use the unarmed attack modifier, or optionally an Acrobatics or Athletics skill check, and counts as an attack action.
annotation.action_economy: 1 action
annotation.prerequisites: The character must be grabbed, immobilized, or restrained.

annotation.summary: On a critical success, the character escapes and removes any grabbed, immobilized, or restrained conditions caused by the target, then may move up to 5 feet.
annotation.action_economy: Free movement up to 5 feet after escaping
annotation.prerequisites: Must be attempting to escape from a grabbed, immobilized, or restrained condition imposed by a target

annotation.summary: On a successful attempt, the character escapes and removes any grabbed, immobilized, or restrained conditions caused by the chosen target.
annotation.action_economy: Varies (typically one action, depending on system rules)
annotation.prerequisites: Must be affected by grabbed, immobilized, or restrained conditions from a specific target

annotation.summary: The Release action allows a character to let go of something they are holding, such as dropping an item or freeing a hand from a weapon. It is a simple action that does not trigger reactions tied to the manipulate trait.
annotation.action_economy: 1 action
annotation.prerequisites: You must be holding an item or object to release.

annotation.summary: The Seek action allows a character to examine an area for hidden creatures, objects, or hazards within a limited range determined by the GM, typically up to 30 feet. The GM may apply penalties or modify the number of actions required based on distance or clutter.
annotation.action_economy: 1 action (may vary based on GM discretion)
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: Speaking requires no action and can be done as long as a character can act, typically limited to a short sentence per round. Special speech-based skill uses, like Deception to Lie, require actions. Speech has the auditory trait, while other communication methods, such as sign language, may have different traits.
annotation.action_economy: Free (no action required for normal speech); specific speech-based skill checks require actions as defined by their rules.
annotation.prerequisites: The character must be able to act and communicate (e.g., not silenced or otherwise prevented from speaking).

annotation.summary: The character moves 5 feet without provoking reactions that normally trigger from movement, such as attacks of opportunity.
annotation.action_economy: 1 action
annotation.prerequisites: The character must have at least 5 feet of movement available and cannot be impeded by effects that prevent movement.

annotation.summary: The character uses their surroundings to gain improved defensive benefits from cover, increasing bonuses to AC, Reflex saves, and Stealth checks until they move, attack, become unconscious, or end the effect.
annotation.action_economy: Free action to end; otherwise passive while stationary
annotation.prerequisites: Must be adjacent to or behind an obstacle that provides cover

annotation.summary: Certain actions have specific requirements: Arrest a Fall, Burrow, and Fly need special movement types; Area Fire and Auto-Fire require weapons with matching traits; and climb and swim actions use Athletics skill rules.
annotation.action_economy: Varies by action; depends on the specific action being performed.

annotation.summary: You make an area attack using your weapon's range or explosion radius. Targets in the area must attempt a basic Reflex save against your class DC plus the weapon's tracking value instead of you making an attack roll. Critical failures trigger the weapon's critical hit effects. The attack consumes expend equal to the weapon's listed value.
annotation.action_economy: Varies by weapon or ability; typically one attack action
annotation.prerequisites: Must have a weapon capable of area fire and sufficient expend value

annotation.summary: You make an automatic area attack in a cone equal to half the weapon’s range increment. Each creature in the area takes weapon damage with a basic Reflex save against your class DC plus the weapon’s tracking value. Critical failures trigger the weapon’s critical hit and specialization effects. The attack expends ammunition equal to twice the number of targets in the area.
annotation.action_economy: 1 action (attack)
annotation.prerequisites: Must be wielding a ranged weapon capable of auto-fire.

annotation.summary: Describes the mechanics of flying movement, including upward and downward movement costs, hovering, and falling if no Fly action is taken.
annotation.action_economy: Requires an action to Fly or to hover in place.
annotation.prerequisites: Must have a fly Speed.

annotation.summary: You can choose one ongoing magical effect you control and extend its duration by sustaining it, typically until the end of your next turn. Effects without a listed sustain duration can be maintained for up to 10 minutes.
annotation.action_economy: Requires the Sustain action, typically one action per effect sustained.
annotation.prerequisites: You must have an active effect with a sustained duration or a listed benefit when sustained.

annotation.summary: Some effects grant extra benefits when you use the Sustain action, even if they don't normally have a sustained duration. If an effect has both a sustained duration and a special benefit, sustaining it provides both the duration extension and the extra benefit.
annotation.action_economy: Requires a Sustain action to trigger the additional benefit and/or extend duration.
annotation.prerequisites: The effect must specify a benefit when sustained or have a sustained duration.

annotation.summary: Describes how movement functions differently across play modes, noting that exploration and downtime movement are flexible while encounter mode uses specific tactical rules.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified; general movement principles apply across modes.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies to all characters in any mode of play.

annotation.summary: Describes special movement types such as flying or swimming, each with its own Speed value. These movement types require specific actions instead of a normal Stride or Step. Speed values can be modified by bonuses or penalties but generally cannot drop below 5 feet.
annotation.action_economy: Requires a special action instead of Stride or Step when using nonstandard movement types.
annotation.prerequisites: Creature must have the corresponding movement type (e.g., fly, swim, burrow) to use that Speed.

annotation.summary: Changing from one type of movement to another ends the current movement action and requires starting a new action for the next movement type. The GM may allow exceptions for very short transitions.
annotation.action_economy: Each movement type requires its own action; switching consumes a new action.
annotation.prerequisites: Must be capable of performing both movement types; subject to GM approval for exceptions.

annotation.summary: Describes situations where Athletics checks are required or optional when climbing, including hazardous or difficult surfaces, and notes that having a climb Speed provides a +4 circumstance bonus to Athletics checks to Climb.
annotation.action_economy: Varies depending on the Climb action; typically one action per Climb attempt.
annotation.prerequisites: Must have a climb Speed to gain the +4 circumstance bonus; otherwise, must be able to attempt Athletics checks to Climb.

annotation.summary: Creatures with a fly Speed can use the Fly and Arrest a Fall actions, and if trained in Acrobatics, they can also attempt to Maneuver in Flight.
prerequisites: Trained in Acrobatics (for Maneuver in Flight)

annotation.summary: Wind direction modifies flying movement: moving against the wind counts as difficult or greater difficult terrain, while moving with the wind doubles movement distance. These effects are not cumulative with downward movement bonuses.
annotation.action_economy: Affects the Fly action's movement cost and distance based on wind direction.
annotation.prerequisites: Creature must be capable of flight and subject to wind conditions.

annotation.summary: Movement direction depends on local gravity; in zero gravity, vertical and horizontal movement are equivalent.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified; describes movement conditions rather than actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies when operating in an environment with defined or zero gravity.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that a character may need to make Athletics checks to Swim in difficult conditions or turbulent water. They can also choose to roll instead of taking an automatic success to attempt a critical success. Having a swim Speed provides a +4 circumstance bonus to Athletics checks to Swim.
annotation.action_economy: Varies depending on the Swim action; typically requires an action to attempt the check.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have a swim Speed to gain the +4 circumstance bonus.

annotation.summary: Movement in encounter mode and other precise situations is determined by your Speed and the actions or abilities you use. Different actions like Stride, Step, Swim, or Climb rely on your Speed, while certain feats, items, or augmentations can grant additional movement types such as burrow, fly, or swim. Abilities with the traversal trait allow substituting other movement types for Stride actions.
annotation.action_economy: Movement actions such as Stride, Step, Swim, or Climb consume actions based on their type; traversal abilities may replace Stride actions with other movement types.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have a defined Speed; additional movement types require specific feats, items, or augmentations.

annotation.summary: Explains how movement cost represents the amount of a creature's speed used to move, and that difficult terrain or other conditions can increase the movement required to travel a given distance.
annotation.action_economy: Uses part or all of a creature's movement for the turn.
annotation.prerequisites: Creature must have a defined Speed value.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains how to represent combat encounters on a grid, where each 1-inch square equals 5 feet in-game. It details how movement is measured across the grid and notes that difficult terrain increases movement cost.
annotation.action_economy: Movement is measured in 5-foot increments per grid square; difficult terrain increases movement cost.
annotation.prerequisites: An encounter involving combat and a grid or map to represent positions.

annotation.summary: Diagonal movement alternates between counting as 5 feet and 10 feet per square, starting with 5 feet. This alternating pattern continues across all diagonal movement in a turn and resets at the end of the turn.
annotation.action_economy: Affects movement distance calculation during a creature's movement on its turn.
annotation.prerequisites: Applies when using a grid-based map and measuring movement in feet per square.

annotation.summary: Movement is typically tracked on a flat map, but if creatures move in three dimensions—such as flying or swimming—refer to special rules for handling 3D movement.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; describes spatial representation rather than actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies generally to any situation involving movement.

annotation.summary: Describes how reactions and free actions that trigger from movement work. When a creature uses a move action, reactions such as Reactive Strike can trigger each time the mover leaves a square within another creature’s reach, but only once per move action per reacting creature. If the move action doesn’t involve leaving a square, the trigger occurs at the end of the action.
annotation.action_economy: Reactions and free actions triggered by move actions; limited to one trigger per reacting creature per move action.
annotation.prerequisites: A creature must have a reaction or free action that specifies a trigger involving another creature’s movement.

annotation.summary: Certain actions, like Step, are designed so that they do not provoke reactions or free actions that would normally trigger from movement.
annotation.action_economy: Varies by action; Step is typically a single action.
annotation.prerequisites: None beyond the ability to take the specified action.

annotation.summary: Creatures can move through the space of another creature that is at least three size categories larger or smaller than themselves, but cannot end their movement in that occupied space.
annotation.action_economy: Movement
annotation.prerequisites: Creature size difference of at least three categories between mover and target creature.

annotation.summary: Tiny creatures can move through and occupy the same space as other creatures, and other creatures can also move through or end their movement in a Tiny creature's space.
annotation.action_economy: Movement
annotation.prerequisites: Creature must be Tiny or interacting with a Tiny creature's space.

annotation.summary: Forced movement occurs when an external effect moves a creature or causes it to fall. The distance moved is determined by the effect, not the creature's Speed. Forced movement does not trigger reactions that rely on voluntary movement, and the GM decides in ambiguous cases.
annotation.action_economy: None; forced movement happens outside the creature's turn or as part of another effect.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies whenever an effect causes involuntary movement.

annotation.summary: When forced movement would push a creature into an invalid or impassable space, the movement ends in the last valid space the creature can occupy.
annotation.action_economy: None (applies to forced movement, not an action)
annotation.prerequisites: Occurs only when a creature is subject to forced movement and the destination space is not occupiable.

annotation.summary: Forced movement is typically directed by the source causing it, allowing movement through hazards or dangerous areas unless the effect states otherwise. The GM decides any unclear cases.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; forced movement occurs outside the creature's normal actions.
annotation.prerequisites: An effect or ability that causes forced movement.

annotation.summary: Describes how a creature can move while carrying another creature, treating the carried creature's movement as forced movement and indicating that both typically follow the same path.
annotation.action_economy: Depends on the ability used; no specific action cost stated.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires an ability or effect that allows carrying another creature during movement.

annotation.summary: Iseph uses the Stride action to move a total of 25 feet, accounting for standard and diagonal movement costs. The first diagonal costs 5 feet, and the second diagonal costs 10 feet, exhausting their full movement speed.
annotation.action_economy: 1 action
annotation.prerequisites: Creature must have a listed Speed and available movement for the turn.

annotation.summary: Iseph moves through difficult terrain toward a control panel, calculating movement costs for diagonal and difficult terrain squares until their total Speed is expended.
annotation.action_economy: Uses all available movement for the turn (25 feet of Speed), ending their actions.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have a defined Speed and understand movement rules for difficult terrain and diagonal movement.

annotation.summary: Different types of terrain can hinder movement, cause harm, or create danger, but skilled navigation can provide tactical advantages.
annotation.action_economy: Varies depending on terrain; may require additional movement or actions to traverse.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies to all creatures moving through affected terrain.

annotation.summary: Difficult terrain slows movement by increasing the movement cost for each space entered. Greater difficult terrain increases the cost even more, and stepping into difficult terrain is not allowed.
annotation.action_economy: Affects movement cost; no specific action required but prevents the Step action.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies whenever a creature moves through difficult or greater difficult terrain.

annotation.summary: Jumping movement ignores the terrain being jumped over, and certain abilities like flight or incorporeality can negate movement penalties from difficult terrain.
annotation.action_economy: Varies depending on the action used to initiate movement or jump.
annotation.prerequisites: Ability to jump or possess traits such as flight or incorporeality.

annotation.summary: Abilities that allow a character to ignore difficult terrain also let them move through greater difficult terrain, but they must still pay the additional movement cost associated with difficult terrain.
annotation.action_economy: None (affects movement cost, not actions)
annotation.prerequisites: Must possess an ability that allows ignoring difficult terrain

annotation.summary: Describes the rules for cover, including the bonuses granted by lesser, standard, and greater cover, and how cover affects AC, Reflex saves, and Stealth checks. It also notes that greater cover can be achieved using the Take Cover action and that only standard or greater cover allows a creature to Hide.
annotation.action_economy: Take Cover is a basic action used to increase cover from standard to greater.
annotation.prerequisites: Must be behind an obstacle that provides physical protection or concealment to gain cover benefits.

annotation.summary: Flanking requires you and an ally to position yourselves on opposite sides of an enemy so that a line between your centers passes through opposite sides or corners of the foe’s space. Both participants must be able to act, have the enemy within melee reach, and be capable of making melee or unarmed attacks.
annotation.action_economy: None (positional requirement, not an action)
prerequisites: You and an ally must be on opposite sides of the target
Both must be able to act
Both must have the target within melee reach
Both must be capable of making melee or unarmed attacks
Neither can be under effects preventing attacks

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that using the Stride action to move away is the simplest way to escape being flanked, reducing the risk of attacks and forcing enemies to spend actions to pursue.
annotation.action_economy: Requires one action to Stride.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be able to take the Stride action and have available movement.

annotation.summary: Describes that a character can be affected by various effects originating from spells, magic items, feats, monsters, hazards, the environment, and other characters.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: Some effects in the game require checks to determine their success or outcome, while others automatically take effect without a check. For example, casting a spell like 'fly' works automatically, but using a skill such as Intimidate to Demoralize an opponent requires a check.
annotation.action_economy: Varies depending on the effect; spellcasting and skill use each follow their own action rules.
annotation.prerequisites: None explicitly stated; depends on the specific effect or skill being used.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that most game effects happen instantly when actions are declared, such as moving or using an item, while others persist for a set duration that ends after the specified time. It also notes that spells may have unique duration rules described elsewhere.
annotation.action_economy: Instantaneous actions resolve immediately when declared; some effects have durations that persist until their time expires.
annotation.prerequisites: Player must declare intended actions to the GM; understanding of duration conventions and reference to spell-specific rules on page 300.

annotation.summary: Describes how durations measured in rounds decrease depending on whether the effect is beneficial or detrimental. Beneficial effects count down at the start of the creator's turn, while detrimental effects typically count down at the end of the target's turn.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this rule governs timing, not actions.
annotation.prerequisites: An ongoing effect with a duration measured in rounds.

annotation.summary: Describes that some effects have conditional durations, ending only when specified conditions are fulfilled or no longer apply.
annotation.action_economy: none
annotation.prerequisites: An effect or ability with a conditional duration.

annotation.summary: Describes how certain effects can be ended early using the Dismiss action or maintained using the Sustain action, with sustained effects lasting until the end of the next turn unless extended.
annotation.action_economy: Dismiss and Sustain actions each require an action on your turn.
annotation.prerequisites: The effect must have a sustained duration to be extended or be eligible to end early via the Dismiss action.

annotation.summary: Explains that certain effects need a chosen target and that targeting can fail if the target is undetected, invalid, or protected by another ability.
annotation.action_economy: none
annotation.prerequisites: Must have a valid, detectable target that meets the effect’s targeting requirements.

annotation.summary: Determines how willingness is decided for effects that require a willing target: players decide for their own characters, and the GM decides for NPCs, even if the character is unaware or unconscious.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this rule concerns decision-making, not actions or turns.
annotation.prerequisites: An effect or ability that specifies a 'willing target' condition.

annotation.summary: Defines what qualifies as an ally for effects or abilities, clarifying that an ally is someone on your side other than yourself, and the GM decides in unclear cases.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable
annotation.prerequisites: Effect or ability that references an ally

annotation.summary: Describes how area effects function in the game, noting that each has a point of origin and a defined shape and size. It lists four types of area effects: bursts, cones, emanations, and lines.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: Describes three conditions affecting a character: Sickened causes nausea, Slowed reduces available actions, and Stunned prevents taking actions entirely.
annotation.action_economy: Sickened may impose penalties; Slowed reduces the number of actions per turn; Stunned removes the ability to act.
annotation.prerequisites: None; these conditions are applied by other effects or abilities.

annotation.summary: Explains that certain effects impose conditions on creatures or items, altering their state until the duration expires, the condition is removed, or specific end criteria are met. References the Conditions Appendix for full details.
annotation.action_economy: None; describes ongoing effects rather than actions.
annotation.prerequisites: An effect or ability capable of applying a condition.

annotation.summary: A condition where another creature dictates your actions instead of you.
annotation.action_economy: No independent actions; actions are chosen by the controlling creature.
annotation.prerequisites: You must be under an effect or ability that grants another creature control over you.

annotation.summary: A fatigued character suffers reduced defenses and cannot engage in exploration activities during travel.
annotation.action_economy: Passive condition; no actions required to apply or remove unless specified elsewhere.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have gained the fatigued condition through exertion, effects, or other game mechanics.

annotation.summary: Creatures outside an ability's line of effect are no longer affected by its ongoing area effects and do not need to make saving throws against it.
annotation.action_economy: None
annotation.prerequisites: Applies when an ability has an area and a defined line of effect.

annotation.summary: Line of sight is required for certain effects. You have line of sight if you can accurately perceive the target area and no solid barrier blocks it. Darkness blocks line of sight without darkvision, but partial obstructions like grates usually do not. A small gap, about one foot square, typically suffices, though the GM decides in unclear cases.
annotation.action_economy: None
annotation.prerequisites: Ability to perceive the target area without a solid barrier obstructing view; darkvision may be required in darkness.

annotation.summary: This section explains how area effects function in the game, defining four types—bursts, cones, emanations, and lines—and describing how they are measured and interact with terrain and cover. It also clarifies that the GM decides how such effects influence the environment and unattended objects.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this passage describes spatial mechanics rather than an action type.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies generally to any effect or ability that creates an area.

annotation.summary: Describes the format for listing afflictions, including name, traits, level, and any special details or restrictions. If no level is given, it defaults to the level of the source causing the affliction.

Afflictions with onset times delay their effects until the specified time passes after a failed initial save. If no onset time is listed, the affliction's first stage (or second on a critical failure) takes effect immediately.
annotation.action_economy: None (passive timing mechanic)
annotation.prerequisites: Failure of the initial saving throw against an affliction

annotation.summary: Describes how an affliction applies its effects at each stage, with intervals indicating when those effects occur.
annotation.action_economy: None
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be affected by an affliction with defined stages and intervals.

annotation.summary: At each interval of an affliction, the affected creature makes a saving throw to reduce its stage. Success lowers the stage by one, critical success by two, and if the stage drops below one, the affliction ends until re-exposure.
annotation.action_economy: None; occurs automatically at the end of the listed interval.
annotation.prerequisites: Creature must currently be affected by an affliction with multiple stages and a defined interval.

annotation.summary: When a character fails or critically fails a saving throw against an affliction, the affliction's stage increases by 1 or 2 respectively. The character then experiences the effects of the new stage. If the stage would exceed the maximum listed, the highest stage's effects repeat instead.
annotation.action_economy: None (triggered by saving throw result)
annotation.prerequisites: The character must be affected by an affliction with multiple stages.

annotation.summary: When an affliction advances to a new stage, its listed damage and conditions apply immediately. Conditions follow their normal rules for duration and behavior. Conditions without a set duration persist while the affliction remains at that stage unless otherwise specified.
annotation.action_economy: none
annotation.prerequisites: The character must be affected by an affliction with multiple stages.

annotation.summary: Repeated exposure to the same curse or disease has no additional effect, but repeated exposure to a poison can worsen its stage if you fail the saving throw, without changing its duration or onset time.
annotation.action_economy: None (passive effect triggered by exposure)
annotation.prerequisites: Character must already be affected by the same curse, disease, or poison.

annotation.summary: At stage 3 of the disease, the affected creature takes 2d8 poison damage and becomes sickened 3. Further failed or critically failed saving throws while at stage 3 cause the same effects to repeat.
annotation.action_economy: None (triggered by saving throw result)
annotation.prerequisites: Must be at stage 3 of the disease or fail/critically fail a saving throw at stage 2 or stage 1 leading to stage 3.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that the 'cleanse affliction' spell is commonly accessible to spellcasters and that spells which remove conditions directly, like 'sound body', can also treat diseases and poisons causing those conditions.
annotation.action_economy: Varies by spell; typically a standard or 2-action casting time.
annotation.prerequisites: Ability to cast the relevant spell (e.g., 'cleanse affliction' or 'sound body').

annotation.summary: Describes how counteract checks resolve opposing magical or effect-based forces, determining whether one nullifies the other.
annotation.action_economy: Varies depending on the specific ability or spell used to counteract.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires an effect or ability capable of performing a counteract check.
